docs.lead_paragraph: THE people who work at the Columbia/ HCA division office in Winter Park, Fla., watch what they say to one another. They self-consciously do not speak of the Government's huge fraud investigation of their company or anything related to it. They know that any colleague they talk to might at some point be subpoenaed and that any conversation -- even their jokes -- could end up being regurgitated before a grand jury. So goes work when the law is peeking in the window. Like many other employees, Trudi Kirby, a nurse supervisor at Columbia Park Medical Center in Orlando, Fla., no longer wears her Columbia T-shirts to the gym or the Target food store. She can do without being hectored as she assesses the broccoli. ''You get this, 'Oh, you're the one who took all that money,' '' she said. ''I can't make them realize that it's not me, it's not this hospital.'' She saves the shirts for gardening and slumber.

headline.main: HEALTH CARE'S GIANT: Working Under a Cloud -- A special report.; How Scandal Put an End To the Flag-Waving

docs.abstract: Special Report: Working Under a Cloud discusses adverse impact of Government's huge fraud investigation of Columbia/HCA on company, its employees, its hospitals and their staffs; notes investigation has resulted in such things as hospital employees being hectored in stores with allegations of corruption to layoffs at Columbia's corporate headquarters in Nashville, resulting in increased anxiety among company's 285,000 employees; efforts of Thomas F Frist Jr, recently appointed chief executive of Columbia/HCA, to restore Columbia's reputation discussed; photos; graph traces 12 months of problems at Columbia/HCA (L)
